author: djrtwo
content: High requirements on <@!555483069038198827>'s proposals are limited to highly specialized *builders* not to those that run full nodes nor to validators

author: djrtwo
content: builders, being those economically incentivized to order and package highly specialized content and those that do charge vals a fee for their work

author: schone_wizard
content: who would serve the role of builders? can the network live without them?

author: djrtwo
content: The proposal acknowledges that this separate economic actor is an inevitability due to the economic forces of MEV

author: schone_wizard
content: PBS in general to me, sounds like a great idea, but not at the cost of being dependent on them being a unique elite ruling class with access to capital that the rest don't.

author: djrtwo
content: the idea is thatit's too valuable for someone not to do it. If no one did it, you'd see the shard-data portion of blocks under utilized

author: schone_wizard
content: so you're saying its an emergent property of the beast just because funds/money are left sitting on the table and someone will eventually do it?

author: djrtwo
content: it's not a must that validators outsource the work. and validators could use a public data-tx mempool to include rollup data-txs but without the horsepower of a builder machine, they'd only include small numbers of these

author: djrtwo
content: that is the assumption and what we are seeing in practice thusfar today

author: schone_wizard
content: that's quite depressing, because this to me reads like we went all the way to the far reaches of the galaxy to create protocols that are superior only to find ourselves at the starting point again

author: djrtwo
content:
I don't necessarily agree with how you are reducing this

The security of the protocol does not rely upon builders or having the capabilities of builders. Data availability sampling allows for a secure protocol with user and validator nodes only having resources of a typical consumer machine. 

Additionally, shard-data building and data dissemination (in this proposal) is a task (this is a goal) that can be distributed amongst many participants

author: schone_wizard
content: Perhaps you're right and I am reducing a complicated issue way too far into simplified thinking.  But I can also see how it will paint in the eyes of people who will see Ethereum going from being on par with bitcoin about being 'bad for climate change/environment', go becoming this green alternative, 99% power consumption requirements reduction, only to find ourselves in the end having to explain that this one task still ends up requiring GPUs and being not so environmentally friendly.

author: schone_wizard
content: It's a bit analogous to energy/oil drilling companies investing in green solutions to make themselves look good while on the back side continuing to feed the machine that burns and produces CO2

author: djrtwo
content: ah, I don't think this has anything to do with energy consumption and doesn't really increase it

author: djrtwo
content: in any substantial way

author: djrtwo
content: PoW creates an arms race of capital expenditure  (in the form of hardware production and energy consumption) that scales as the value of the network scales

author: djrtwo
content: This would be a GPU requirement (maybe) for some bound number of economic actors

author: djrtwo
content: call it 100 or 1000 or even 10k (it wouldn't be 10k imo)

author: djrtwo
content: that's 10k GPUs....

author: djrtwo
content: there are easily millions of GPUs (maybe 10M or 100M, not sure current estimate) mining

author: djrtwo
content: and that number increases as the value of eth increaess

author: djrtwo
content: whereas, a builder market would naturally support some equillibrium of builder actors and their requirements

author: djrtwo
content: Think about this -- if we had ~100k nodes on the network instaed of 10k, the post-PoS energy usage would be 10x today (minus the pow mmining of course)

author: djrtwo
content: but that 10x is essentially nothing in comparison to the energy consumption of PoW

author: djrtwo
content: say we go from 99.9 to 99.8 more energy efficinet compared to PoW today

author: schone_wizard
content: perhaps, my argument wasn't well formed.  I wasn't arguing that we are going to be wasting as much energy, but merely that it would be spinned that way.

author: schone_wizard
content: Again maybe i'm over simplifying, but it feels a bit odd to having gone on this journey in proof of stake only to arrive at the point where our protocol, again, requires GPUs even if it's for a differing purpose than what it was using them for originally

author: jgm
content: Block packing is a fundamentally different action to consensus, though.  Not sure that addressing the energy concerns of one should reduce the energy concerns of the other.

content: what's the need for heavy compute required for this?

author: jgm
content: Yes, but a very dynamic one as new transactions are turning up all the time.  Plus additional work to find MEV opportunities, create the relevant transactions, and slot them in to the block, all to increase the returns for the block.
